channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: The economics of megachurches
item.description: Why America’s fastest-growing churches don’t get political

item.title: Donald Trump and the White Man’s Burden in Nigeria
item.description: US President Donald Trump has made good on his threat to take military action against Nigeria to save Christians from a “genocide.” Trump has three possible motives: his mercantilist quest for rare-earth minerals, his pandering to evangelical Christians, and his racist grievances.

item.title: What is the best way to train for a marathon?
Japan’s Long Return to Artificial Intelligence
item.description: Once a pioneer that helped the world lay the foundations of machine learning, Japan’s renewed push into artificial intelligence reflects a search for economic resilience as much as technological relevance.

item.title: Latin America’s Year in Review
item.description: In 2025, the region went up against tariffs, deportations, and a major U.S. military buildup.

item.title: PS Commentators’ Predictions for 2026
item.description: Donald Trump’s second presidency has reset global expectations, making uncertainty the defining feature of today’s geopolitical and economic landscape. While the path forward remains unclear, the year ahead will likely be marked by greater geopolitical and financial turmoil.

item.title: 5 Times Tooze in 2025
item.description: Notable episodes of FP’s economics podcast from the past year.

item.title: The Trump Administration’s Uses, and Abuses, of History
item.description: For better and worse, 2025 was a historical year.

item.title: Japan Accelerates Defense Buildup With Record Budget and Expanded Unmanned Capabilities
item.description: The draft defense budget sets a new spending record for the 12th straight year amid mounting regional threats and U.S. alliance pressure.

item.title: Convergence Amid Divergence: America, China, and the Emerging Minimalist World Order
item.description: The world views of China and the U.S. have come into closer alignment in our current era. They go about the enactment of their policies in significantly different ways.

item.title: How Profit Beat Out Geopolitics in the AI Race
item.description: In 2025, too many people were making too much money to slow down.

item.title: The Year the World Started to Recognize Genocide in Sudan
item.description: International actors may be sounding the alarm, but that doesn’t equate to meaningful action.

item.title: 2025 in review: tech
Modi Government Rings Death Knell of India’s Legal Right to Employment
item.description: The globally acclaimed MGNREGA, enacted when the Congress party was in power, has been replaced by a law that puts in place a discretionary scheme.

item.title: BNP’s Tarique Rahman Returns to Bangladesh After 17 Years in Exile
item.description: The return of the BNP’s acting chairperson is expected to give the party a boost in the upcoming general elections.

item.title: Myanmar’s Election Is Predetermined, but Questions Remain
item.description: Some parts of the country will begin voting on Dec. 28 in polls that could further legitimize the ruling junta.

item.title: How to Secure the Sky
item.description: America needs a defense against drones.

item.title: How China Carved Up Myanmar
item.description: Beijing’s strategy to create stability through dependence.

item.title: How Indian Cinema Has Become a Patriotism Test
item.description: Appreciation or criticism of a movie is no longer interpreted primarily as an aesthetic or ethical judgment. It has become a marker of allegiance or opposition to the state.

item.title: Why Is Myanmar’s Military Bothering to Hold an Election?
item.description: More than four years ago, the military ousted Myanmar's freely elected government at gunpoint. The upcoming polls will be a total sham.
